data.title: extends on Subclass doesn't resolve relative Paths to GDScript
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Ubuntu 14.04

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

extends "MyGDScript.gd" from gdscipt file works 

but:

```
class MySubClass extends "MyGDScript.gd":
    var myvar
```

Doesn't work

but

```
class MySubClass extends "res://absolute/path/MyGDScript.gd":
    var myvar
```

works

**Steps to reproduce:**

create two gdscript files in same folder

"script1.gd and script2.gd for example.

in script2.gd put this code

```
extends "script1.gd" # works

class SubClass extends  "script1.gd": #doesn't work
    var myvar
```

data.title: OS.get_time_from_unix_time(OS.get_unix_time()) returns wrong month at 0 o clock / sunday
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Linux, github build from today

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
it is 0:45 - march  13, sunday, 2016

When I do: print (OS.get_time_from_unix_time(OS.get_unix_time()))
I get: (day:13), (hour:0), (minute:45), (month:2), (second:6), (weekday:0), (year:2016)

When I do: print (OS.get_date())
I get: (day:13), (dst:False), (month:3), (weekday:0), (year:2016)

When I print unix time a few minutes later, I get: 1457830499

Also is weekday 0 sunday? :)

data.title: How to draw a rawarray Image
data.body:
Right now I have to save my rawarray(image) first but I want to show it without saving to the drive.

var image_as_raw_array = []#is filled with an png image from www
var path = "res://cache.png"

```
if(f.open( path, File.WRITE )==0):
    f.store_buffer( image_as_raw_array )
    f.close()

    var img = ImageTexture.new()
    img.load( path )

    preview_sprite.set_texture( img )
```

Is there a way without "img.load( path )" something like img.load( rawarray )?

http://www.godotengine.org/qa/744/how-to-draw-a-rawarray-image

data.title: FileDialog open File and Dir MODE_OPEN_ANY
data.body:
closes #4019

How to use/test?

Select a file and you will see a file selected print
Select a dir and you will see a dir selected print

```
extends Node2D

onready var filedialog = get_node( "FileDialog" )

func _ready():
    filedialog.connect("dir_selected", self,"_on_FileDialog_dir_selected")
    filedialog.connect("file_selected", self,"_on_FileDialog_file_selected")
    filedialog.connect("files_selected", self,"_on_FileDialog_files_selected")

    filedialog.set_mode( filedialog.MODE_OPEN_ANY )
    #filedialog.set_mode( filedialog.MODE_SAVE_FILE )
    #filedialog.set_mode( filedialog.MODE_OPEN_FILES )
    #filedialog.set_mode( filedialog.MODE_OPEN_FILE )
    filedialog.popup()

func _on_FileDialog_dir_selected( dir ):
    print("dir selected: " + dir )


func _on_FileDialog_file_selected( path ):
    print("file selected: " + path )

func _on_FileDialog_files_selected( paths ):
    print("files selected: " + str(paths) )
```

data.title: [SECURITY] CWE-330/CWE-676 - rand() used for cryptographic purpose
data.body:
Godot uses `rand()` in `crypthead` function in [/core/io/crypt.h](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/master/core/io/crypt.h) for encryption which is **unsecure**. We should at least use `/dev/random` on POSIX-like systems ( x11/os x/android?/ios? ) and [CryptGenRandom](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/aa379942%28v=vs.85%29.aspx) function on Windows for crypto.

Btw. we also have some version of openssl ( is it the secure one, after heartbleeds etc. ? ) - maybe we can use randoms from it.

data.title: Additional Exporting Mode for Optimized Binary Size and Game Performance
data.body:
**A.] As we know, Godot has One mode for exporting a godot project.**

We just need to make sure that Export Template for desired platform there, and then hit Export Button. But with C++, we need to re-compile our game on every changes we made, and also need to compile export template before hit Export button. By using GDScript, we'll most likely get fast made Game with "acceptable" performance. Instead, we'll wait some minutes even hours to compile and re-compile for a higher performance game.

Still, both have the same downside, non-optimized binary size. A simple "HelloWord" game will have similar size as a simple "Jumper" game.

**B.] Compiling for Release Mode with AutoConverted GDScript to CPP**

As usual, coding the game using GDScript, fast prototyping as we have every changes done in second. And, whenever we think our game ready to be released, we are provided Two ways of Exporting.

1) Just like what Godot have now. There is export template. Hit Export button and the engine Start exporting. A short description could be added though, for example: "Fast Exporting. No need to spend some minutes or hours."

2) Compiling for Release. A Short description: "Slow Exporting. Could take some minutes or hours. Be warned". In this mode, the engine automatically convert all GDScript files into CPP and gather all resources first and then start Compiling (when it comes to Android, the engine calling Android NDK Toolchain).

This way, we could have 3 advantages:
- Make games faster (thanks to GDScript)
- Optimized binary size
- Having C++ performance (thanks to something like gdscript_to_cpp conveter and "compiling for release" mode).

**C.] Where the idea comes from?**
- Cocos Studio. It has Two modes for exporting project:
  1) Using pre-made libraries. The libraries are static. No need to compile on every changes. Take a few minutes. Bigger binary size and less performance if we use JavaScript as Scripting Language.
  2) Compiling the whole project for release. Takes minutes or hours (depend on machine rig), but well optimized binary size and performance.
- GameMaker Studio. It also has Two modes for exporting project:
  1) Export using Non-YYC (default mode). This way, GML (GameMaker Scripting Language) packed together with other resources and interpreted at runtime. Fast Export, but less performance.
  2) Export using YYC (YoYo Compiler). This way, GML and other related resources is converted into CPP by YoYoCompiler and then compiling to .so file done by Android NDK Toolchain (of course if we target Android Apk). Once the game compiled, there is .ini file that said something like, LLVM. Probably it's kind of modified LLVM Compiler. Long Export, but the performance much better.
- Unity3D. Two modes for exporting project provided:
  1) Using C# (Mono C# Compiler)
  2) Using IL2CPP (Intermediate Language To CPP. Convert Mono C# Compiler to C++ Compiler). More Info: http://blogs.unity3d.com/2015/05/06/an-introduction-to-ilcpp-internals/

http://blogs.unity3d.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/il2cpp-toolchain-smaller.png

Or, other methods which supposed to give better optimization on binary size and performance is most welcomed.

Edit 1: Added IL2CPP which used by Unity3D

data.title: Discussion about 3D features: bones, IK, ragdolls
data.body:
I'm sorry to bother by this things, but I need to make some things clear.
I have the following set of features I need from Godot andI wonder about plans and opinions on
implementing this. I just need comments on how hard to implemnt this and that, ideas on implementation, plans, details, anything. I hope I'm not alone interested in this, but any attempt 
to start discussion failed so far, so I'd like to try this way.
1. More user friendly bone transform editing and animation. Should allow quaternion
   and XYZ angles, scale, transform, animation of the fields, from GUI. Being implemented for everything else, it is just natural to have this for bones too. That would allow to animate skeletons from Godot
   without having to calculate transformation matrices by hand
2. Bone constraints - we need to be able to limit bone rotation, this is requirement for 3.
   Can be done in a way similar to Blender, just rotational constraints with angles, on XYZ and quaternion
   coordinates, global and local.
3. Inverse kinematics. We have this feature for 2D, but 3D one is a bit more complex,
   requires 2 targets, the IK target and pole target to be sloved right. This can be implemented in GDScript now, but done this way is messy without having 0.1 and 1.
4. Ragdoll - this can be implemented in many different ways, including via 1. plus applied constraints, with forces applied to IK targets and bases. But better use some fast published solution, which
   are available a lot.

My opinion about this is that the start should be with 0. and 1. but I might be wrong here,
as I'm not professional in this field, but I'm really curious and interested, and have an attitude.
Any ideas?

data.title: Added configurable tab size in the text editor.
data.body: Added an option to configure the tab sizes in the text editor.

data.title: Translated strings shouldn't escape '\n'
data.body:
**Operating system or device:** Linux

**Issue description** I have a couple of strings which have '\n' in the middle (bigger sentences). When calling tr(), the returned string has '\n' as a string instead of a newline character, thus messing up the final result. I confirmed this by doing a `tr('string').replace("\\\n","\n")` which produced the intended result.

Fix npot(not power of two) dds texture loading bug
Use squish::DecompressImage to decompress BC1/BC2/BC3 image

data.title: Search Help showing no results for "OS"
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Linux Mint 17.3

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When using "Search Help" to search classes in the engine, I noticed that for some reason you can't directly search for the OS class because the search only starts with a minimum for 3 characters. So the simple workaround is just to search "OS." and press on one of the methods, but it's still a little awkward.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Press "Script"
2. Press "Search Help"
3. Type in "OS"
4. Then type "OS." to get results but no direct "OS (class)" search result

**PS**
Sorry for wasting your time with such a tiny issue... but my "OCD" made me do it :(

data.title: TileSet Export: Avoid invalid error when merge is enabled but file doesn't exist

Regression from #3280

This error (`Can't load TileSet for merging!`) should only appear if the resource could not be loaded, not if it (the file) doesn't exist.

data.title: (whoops)
Request: Reparent node, maintaining transform
data.body:
I would like to request a method added to CanvasItem object:

`CanvasItem.reparent( new_parent, keep_world_transform=false )`

The method would un-parent node from its current parent, and add itself as child to `new_parent`. If `keep_world_transform` is true, it would maintain its transform relative to scene root ( so `get_global_transform()` before the call and after would return the same transform ). After this call, with `keep_world_transform` true, the node would not appear to move, but switch parent.

Additionally, this method would NOT call `_exit_tree` or `_enter_tree` methods unless new_parent is not part of display tree.

I suspect it could be a pretty easy thing to add to engine itself, and kind of a pain to do in GD Script.

As an example, I'm using similar functionality to transplant player character from "room" to "room". Each "room" is dynamically loaded / discarded, and has own transform.

data.title: Fix a crash when running a game with Controls with a tools build
data.body:
Regression from #3997

`TOOLS_ENABLED` is defined, when running from an editor binary, but `EDITOR_DEF` crashes if `SceneTree::editor_hint` is false.

Sorry about that one...

data.title: Several improvements for the Tilemap editor
data.body:
I'm working on some improvements in the built-in Tilemap editor, based on some issues, mainly #843:
- [x] Rectangular drawing and erasing.  
  `Ctrl+Shift+L_DRAG`: Draw.  
  `Ctrl+Shift+R_DRAG`: Erase.
- [x] Line drawing and erasing.  
  Uses the Bresenham's line algorithm.  
  `Shift+L_DRAG`: Draw.  
  `Shift+R_DRAG`: Erase.  
  ~~Brush size.~~
- [x] Bucket fill.  
  It uses a Flood Fill algorithm, and uses the node rect as limit.  
  `Missing shortcut`  
- [x] Search by name on the palette.  
  `Ctrl+F`: Will focus the search box if the 2D editor has the focus.  
  ~~Zoom for the tile palette.~~
- [x] Tilemap menu in the 2D editor toolbar.

And i made some small additions and changes:
- Shift+B for box select.
- Duplicate preview.
- When duplicating the original selection is preserved.
- Removed list display.

Suggestions are welcome.

data.title: Open adaptive music library module
data.body:
Just throwing this as an idea, I haven't looked much into it but it looks like something that could be useful in some games, and it's MIT licensed: https://github.com/marcelofg55/oaml

I'm not necessarily proposing to get this integrated into master directly, but maybe some community member would like to write a module for it. Though if there's enough community interest (and if the library is actually good and adaptable to our API), I guess it could be added in the main tree too.

data.title: Any non-latin symbols make debugger swear
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Windows 10

**Issue description** what happened, and what was expected):
I live in Russia, so I do have russian keyboard layout and if I write some russian letters or whatever it will not appear in the editor, and i won't be able to erase it or backspace. And I also won't be able to compile the code. The only way out is to undo the action by pressing Ctrl-Z.

Just letting you know :)

data.title: Particle2D emitting settings create unexpected results.
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
xubuntu 14.04 64-bit running newly compiled Godot from github. Also confirmed with a versions from 3 days ago.

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

I would expect that Particle2D setting amount to 1, lifetime to 1, timescale 1, preprocess 0.1, emit timeout 0.9 and explosiveness to 1 would create exactly one particle emitted when is_emitting(true) is called (or just Emitting check box checked in Inspector).
However it does not.
You have to set amount to a higher value to see particle or particles emitted (they might be one on top of another).
Also, setting explosiveness to 0 seems buggy too. At 0 you must bump up timeout to 1.1 to see emitted particle or particles.

data.title: Export HTML5 demos on releasing
data.body:
http://www.godotengine.org/download (and other pages) doesn't showcase Godot capabilities in HTML5 export, which is essential for many game jams to share your creations.

I'd expect to just find links to all exported demos so that I click through them for each release to estimate maturity, track progress and add more (problematic) demos.

data.title: Error on project close (Segfault in /usr/lib/nvidia-304/libnvidia-glcore.so.304.131)
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Ubuntu 14.04 Unity 64-bit

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

WARNING: cleanup: ObjectDB Instances still exist!
   At: core/object.cpp:1904.
ERROR: clear: Resources Still in use at Exit!
   At: core/resource.cpp:357.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Open a Project.
2. Scene -> quit to project list.
3. Open a Project while in the background the previous project is still closing.

I also get this error on
1. Open a Project.
2. Scene -> Quit
